newsitem.title: USA: N.Dakota wheat gets more rain but condition ebbs.
newsitem.headline: N.Dakota wheat gets more rain but condition ebbs.

text.p: Showers and thunderstorms brought more relief to North Dakota crops during the week ended Sunday, the state's agricultural statistics service said Monday in its weekly crop progress report.

But the report said small grain development remained below average despite the rains. Topsoil moisture was slightly replenished, but conditions continued to be much drier than last year. The condition of all crops except sugarbeets and sunflowers deteriorated during the week, the report said.
Forty-five percent of the state's spring wheat crop rated good or excellent, against 54 at that level last week.
Spring wheat was 48 percent jointing, ahead of 16 last week, 34 last year and the five-year average of 57 percent.
Durum wheat jointing 31 pct vs 11 w/a, 21 y/a, 42 avge.
Oats jointing 42 pct vs 12 w/a, 30 y/a, 56 avge.
Barley jointing 43 pct vs 14 w/a, 36 y/a, 59 avge.
Corn emerged 100 pct vs 95 w/a, 99 y/a, 98 avge.
Soybeans emerged 98 pct vs 92 w/a, 96 y/a, 97 avge.
Sugarbeets emerged 100 pct vs 97 w/a, 100 y/a, 100 avge.
Sunflowers emerged 95 pct vs 79 w/a, 94 y/a, 92 avge.
Topsoil moisture conditions improved and were rated 61 percent short to very short, against 73 in that category last week, 14 percent last year and the average of 19 percent.
